Binding: Artifact Relationship Type (Extensible)

note 0..*AnnotationFootnotes and/or explanatory notes

description 0..1markdownA text description or summary of the variable
note 0..*AnnotationFootnotes and/or explanatory notes

Documentation for this format

name: Evidence
description: The Evidence Resource provides a machine-interpretable expression of an evidence concept including the evidence variables (e.g., population, exposures/interventions, comparators, outcomes, measured variables, confounding variables), the statistics, and the certainty of this evidence.

element.short: Single evidence bit
element.definition: The Evidence Resource provides a machine-interpretable expression of an evidence concept including the evidence variables (e.g., population, exposures/interventions, comparators, outcomes, measured variables, confounding variables), the statistics, and the certainty of this evidence.

constraint.human: Name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation

element.short: Logical id of this artifact
element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: Within the context of the FHIR RESTful interactions, the resource has an id except for cases like the create and conditional update. Otherwise, the use of the resouce id depends on the given use case.

element.short: Metadata about the resource
element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc. For DomainResources, if more than one implicitRules policy applies, additional policies may be conveyed using the [additionalImplicitRules](https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/fhir-extensions/StructureDefinition-additionalImplicitRules.html) extension.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of its narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies its meaning or interpretation

element.short: Language of the resource content
element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: IETF language tag for a human language

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have a narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Contained, inline Resources
element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, nor can they have their own independent transaction scope. This is allowed to be a Parameters resource if and only if it is referenced by a resource that provides context/meaning.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags in their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels. Contained resources may be a resource type defined in the FHIR specification, or an [additional resource](resource.html#additional).

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. To make the use of extensions safe and managable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and managable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the resource that contains them

element.short: Canonical identifier for this evidence, represented as a globally unique URI
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this evidence when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which an authoritative instance of this summary is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the summary is stored on different servers.
element.comment: In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the meta.source element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.
element.requirements: Allows the evidence to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

constraint.human: URL should not contain | or # - these characters make processing canonical references problematic
All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Additional identifier for the summary
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this summary when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Business version of this summary
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the summary when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the summary author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
element.comment: The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author. Considerations for making this decision are found in Technical and Business Versions.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: How to compare versions
element.definition: Indicates the mechanism used to compare versions to determine which is more current.
element.comment: If set as a string, this is a FHIRPath expression that has two additional context variables passed in - %version1 and %version2 and will return a negative number if version1 is newer, a positive number if version2 is newer, and a 0 if the version ordering can't successfully be determined.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Name for this summary (machine friendly)
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the evidence. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Name for this summary (human friendly)
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the summary.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Display of how to cite this Evidence
element.definition: Display of the suggested method of how to cite this Evidence.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: draft | active | retired | unknown
element.definition: The status of this summary. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.comment:
Allows filtering of summaries that are appropriate for use versus not.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired Evidence without due consideration

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.short: For testing only - never for real usage
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this resource is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and no version of this resource will ever be intended for genuine usage.
element.comment:
Allows filtering of artifacts that are appropriate for use versus not. Experimental resources might include example instances in implementation guides, instances created solely for testing purposes, etc. If experimental is 'true' for any version of a resource, it should be true for all versions of the resource.  (If experimental changes, then it is being misused or a resource that was never intended for real-world use has unexpectedly changed its purpose.).

Experimental resources are not expected to be stable and may well have breaking changes without a corresponding change to the 'version' element.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If absent, this resource is treated as though it is not experimental.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Date last changed
element.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the summary was last significantly changed. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the summary changes.
element.comment:
The date is often not tracked until the resource is published, but may be present on draft content. Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the summary. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: When the summary was approved by publisher
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was approved by the publisher. Approval happens once when the content is officially approved for usage.
element.comment:
The 'date' element may be more recent than the approval date because of minor changes or editorial corrections.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: When the summary was last reviewed by the publisher
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was last reviewed. Review happens periodically after approval but does not change the original approval date.
element.comment:
If specified, this date follows the original approval date.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).
element.requirements: Gives a sense of how "current" the content is.  Resources that have not been reviewed in a long time may have a risk of being less appropriate/relevant.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Who authored the content
element.definition: An individiual, organization, or device primarily involved in the creation and maintenance of the content.
element.comment: Extensions to ContactDetail include: contactReference, contactAddress, and contributionTime (see [Clinical Reasoning Module](clinicalreasoning-module.html)).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Name of the publisher/steward (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual responsible for the release and ongoing maintenance of the evidence.
element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the evidence is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the evidence. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the evidence. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the evidence.  May also allow for contact.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Contact details for the publisher
element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comment:
Extensions to ContactDetail include: contactReference, contactAddress, and contributionTime (see [Clinical Reasoning Module](clinicalreasoning-module.html)).

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Who entered the data for the evidence
element.definition: Who entered the data for the evidence.
element.comment: The Evidence.recorder element is structured to support a name (with a string datatype) and contact point information for the recorder, and is not structured to support unique identifiers for the recorder. If detailed contributorship data is needed, then one can create a Citation Resource for the Evidence Resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Who edited the content
element.definition: An individiual, organization, or device primarily responsible for internal coherence of the content.
element.comment: Extensions to ContactDetail include: contactReference, contactAddress, and contributionTime (see [Clinical Reasoning Module](clinicalreasoning-module.html)).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Who reviewed the content
element.definition: An individiual, organization, or device primarily responsible for review of some aspect of the content.
element.comment:
Extensions to ContactDetail include: contactReference, contactAddress, and contributionTime (see [Clinical Reasoning Module](clinicalreasoning-module.html)).

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Who endorsed the content
element.definition: An individiual, organization, or device responsible for officially endorsing the content for use in some setting.
element.comment:
Extensions to ContactDetail include: contactReference, contactAddress, and contributionTime (see [Clinical Reasoning Module](clinicalreasoning-module.html)).

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The context that the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate evidence instances.
element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Why this Evidence is defined
element.definition: Explanation of why this Evidence is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the Evidence. Instead, it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is. This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this Evidence.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Intellectual property ownership, may include restrictions on use
element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the Evidence and/or its contents. Copyright statements are legal notices of intellectual property ownership and may include restrictions on the use and publishing of the Evidence.
element.comment: The short copyright declaration (e.g. (c) '2015+ xyz organization') should be sent in the copyrightLabel element without the copyright prefix (i.e., do not include '(c)' or the symbol).
element.requirements: Consumers must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the Evidence and/or its content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Copyright holder and year(s)
element.definition: A short string (<50 characters), suitable for inclusion in a page footer that identifies the copyright holder, effective period, and optionally whether rights are restricted. (e.g. 'All rights reserved', 'Some rights reserved').
element.comment: The copyright symbol and the '(c)' textual representation SHOULD NOT be included in this string. It will be added by software when rendering the notation. Full details about licensing, restrictions, warrantees, etc. goes in the more general 'copyright' element.
element.requirements: Defines the content expected to be rendered in all representations of the artifact.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Relationships to other Resources
element.definition: Relationships that this Evidence has with other FHIR or non-FHIR resources that already exist.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children or both

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and managable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).

The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

element.definition: The type of relationship to the related artifact.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The type of relationship to the related artifact.

element.short: The artifact that is related to this Evidence
element.definition: The artifact that is related to this Evidence Resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Description of the particular summary
element.definition: A natural language summary of the evidence.
element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the evidence as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the evidence is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the evidence was created).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Declarative description of the Evidence
element.definition: Declarative description of the Evidence, such as conclusion or bottom line statement.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Footnotes and/or explanatory notes
element.definition: Footnotes and/or explanatory notes.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Description, classification, and definition of a single variable
element.definition: Description, classification, and definition of a single variable. The collection of variables defines what the evidence is about.
element.comment: Comparative evidence is often defined with a population variable, an exposure variable and an outcome variable, while non comparative evidence is often defined with a population variable and an outcome variable.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children or both

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing

element.short: The number of events associated with the statistic
element.definition: The number of events associated with the statistic, where the unit of analysis is different from numberAffected, sampleSize.knownDataCount and sampleSize.numberOfParticipants.
element.comment: When the number of events is the statistic, use Evidence.statistic.quantity and set Evidence.statistic.type.coding.code=C25463 and Evidence.statistic.type.coding.display=Count. When the statistic is an Event Rate (where individual participants may have 2 or more events), use Evidence.statistic.numberOfEvents to record the total number of events rather than the number of participants with events.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The number of participants affected
element.definition: The number of participants affected where the unit of analysis is the same as sampleSize.knownDataCount and sampleSize.numberOfParticipants.
element.comment: When the number affected is the statistic, use Evidence.statistic.quantity and set Evidence.statistic.type.coding.code=C25463 and Evidence.statistic.type.coding.display=Count. When the statistic is a Proportion, use Evidence.statistic.numberAffected and enter an integer as the value. When the statistic is an Event Rate (where individual participants may have 2 or more events), use Evidence.statistic.numberAffected to record the number of participants with events rather than the total number of events.

constraint.human: Name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation

element.short: Canonical identifier for this evidence, represented as a globally unique URI
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this evidence when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which an authoritative instance of this summary is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the summary is stored on different servers.
element.comment: In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the meta.source element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.
element.requirements: Allows the evidence to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

constraint.human: URL should not contain | or # - these characters make processing canonical references problematic

element.short: Additional identifier for the summary
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this summary when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

element.short: Business version of this summary
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the summary when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the summary author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
element.comment: The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author. Considerations for making this decision are found in Technical and Business Versions.

element.short: How to compare versions
element.definition: Indicates the mechanism used to compare versions to determine which is more current.
element.comment: If set as a string, this is a FHIRPath expression that has two additional context variables passed in - %version1 and %version2 and will return a negative number if version1 is newer, a positive number if version2 is newer, and a 0 if the version ordering can't successfully be determined.

element.short: Name for this summary (machine friendly)
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the evidence. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.

element.short: Name for this summary (human friendly)
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the summary.

element.short: Display of how to cite this Evidence
element.definition: Display of the suggested method of how to cite this Evidence.

element.short: draft | active | retired | unknown
element.definition: The status of this summary. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.comment:
Allows filtering of summaries that are appropriate for use versus not.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).
element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired Evidence without due consideration

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.short: For testing only - never for real usage
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this resource is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and no version of this resource will ever be intended for genuine usage.
element.comment:
Allows filtering of artifacts that are appropriate for use versus not. Experimental resources might include example instances in implementation guides, instances created solely for testing purposes, etc. If experimental is 'true' for any version of a resource, it should be true for all versions of the resource.  (If experimental changes, then it is being misused or a resource that was never intended for real-world use has unexpectedly changed its purpose.).

Experimental resources are not expected to be stable and may well have breaking changes without a corresponding change to the 'version' element.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If absent, this resource is treated as though it is not experimental.

element.short: Date last changed
element.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the summary was last significantly changed. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the summary changes.
element.comment:
The date is often not tracked until the resource is published, but may be present on draft content. Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the summary. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

element.short: When the summary was approved by publisher
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was approved by the publisher. Approval happens once when the content is officially approved for usage.
element.comment:
The 'date' element may be more recent than the approval date because of minor changes or editorial corrections.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

element.short: When the summary was last reviewed by the publisher
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was last reviewed. Review happens periodically after approval but does not change the original approval date.
element.comment:
If specified, this date follows the original approval date.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).
element.requirements: Gives a sense of how "current" the content is.  Resources that have not been reviewed in a long time may have a risk of being less appropriate/relevant.

element.short: Who authored the content
element.definition: An individiual, organization, or device primarily involved in the creation and maintenance of the content.
element.comment: Extensions to ContactDetail include: contactReference, contactAddress, and contributionTime (see [Clinical Reasoning Module](clinicalreasoning-module.html)).

element.short: Name of the publisher/steward (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual responsible for the release and ongoing maintenance of the evidence.
element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the evidence is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the evidence. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the evidence. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the evidence.  May also allow for contact.

element.short: Contact details for the publisher
element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comment:
Extensions to ContactDetail include: contactReference, contactAddress, and contributionTime (see [Clinical Reasoning Module](clinicalreasoning-module.html)).

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

element.short: Who entered the data for the evidence
element.definition: Who entered the data for the evidence.
element.comment: The Evidence.recorder element is structured to support a name (with a string datatype) and contact point information for the recorder, and is not structured to support unique identifiers for the recorder. If detailed contributorship data is needed, then one can create a Citation Resource for the Evidence Resource.

element.short: Who edited the content
element.definition: An individiual, organization, or device primarily responsible for internal coherence of the content.
element.comment: Extensions to ContactDetail include: contactReference, contactAddress, and contributionTime (see [Clinical Reasoning Module](clinicalreasoning-module.html)).

element.short: Who reviewed the content
element.definition: An individiual, organization, or device primarily responsible for review of some aspect of the content.
element.comment:
Extensions to ContactDetail include: contactReference, contactAddress, and contributionTime (see [Clinical Reasoning Module](clinicalreasoning-module.html)).

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

element.short: Who endorsed the content
element.definition: An individiual, organization, or device responsible for officially endorsing the content for use in some setting.
element.comment:
Extensions to ContactDetail include: contactReference, contactAddress, and contributionTime (see [Clinical Reasoning Module](clinicalreasoning-module.html)).

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

element.short: The context that the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate evidence instances.
element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

element.short: Why this Evidence is defined
element.definition: Explanation of why this Evidence is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the Evidence. Instead, it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is. This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this Evidence.

element.short: Intellectual property ownership, may include restrictions on use
element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the Evidence and/or its contents. Copyright statements are legal notices of intellectual property ownership and may include restrictions on the use and publishing of the Evidence.
element.comment: The short copyright declaration (e.g. (c) '2015+ xyz organization') should be sent in the copyrightLabel element without the copyright prefix (i.e., do not include '(c)' or the symbol).
element.requirements: Consumers must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the Evidence and/or its content.

element.short: Copyright holder and year(s)
element.definition: A short string (<50 characters), suitable for inclusion in a page footer that identifies the copyright holder, effective period, and optionally whether rights are restricted. (e.g. 'All rights reserved', 'Some rights reserved').
element.comment: The copyright symbol and the '(c)' textual representation SHOULD NOT be included in this string. It will be added by software when rendering the notation. Full details about licensing, restrictions, warrantees, etc. goes in the more general 'copyright' element.
element.requirements: Defines the content expected to be rendered in all representations of the artifact.

element.short: Relationships to other Resources
element.definition: Relationships that this Evidence has with other FHIR or non-FHIR resources that already exist.

element.short: documentation | justification | citation | predecessor | successor | derived-from | depends-on | composed-of | part-of | amends | amended-with | appends | appended-with | cites | cited-by | comments-on | comment-in | contains | contained-in | corrects | correction-in | replaces | replaced-with | retracts | retracted-by | signs | similar-to | supports | supported-with | transforms | transformed-into | transformed-with | documents | specification-of | created-with | cite-as | reprint | reprint-of | summarizes
element.definition: The type of relationship to the related artifact.

binding.description: The type of relationship to the related artifact.

element.short: The artifact that is related to this Evidence
element.definition: The artifact that is related to this Evidence Resource.

element.short: Description of the particular summary
element.definition: A natural language summary of the evidence.
element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the evidence as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the evidence is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the evidence was created).

element.short: Declarative description of the Evidence
element.definition: Declarative description of the Evidence, such as conclusion or bottom line statement.

element.short: Footnotes and/or explanatory notes
element.definition: Footnotes and/or explanatory notes.

element.short: Description, classification, and definition of a single variable
element.definition: Description, classification, and definition of a single variable. The collection of variables defines what the evidence is about.
element.comment: Comparative evidence is often defined with a population variable, an exposure variable and an outcome variable, while non comparative evidence is often defined with a population variable and an outcome variable.

element.short: A text description or summary of the variable
element.definition: A text description or summary of the variable.

element.short: Footnotes and/or explanatory notes
element.definition: Footnotes and/or explanatory notes.

element.short: population | exposure | outcome | covariate
element.definition: Classification of the role of the variable.

binding.description: The role that the variable plays.

element.short: Sub-classification of the role of the variable
element.definition: Sub-classification of the role of the variable.
element.comment: See the Evidence Based Medicine on FHIR Implementation Guide (https://hl7.org/fhir/uv/ebm) for Extensible and Preferred value sets for evidence-related terminologies.

binding.description: The sub-role that the variable plays.

element.short: The reference value used for comparison
element.definition: The reference value used for comparison.
element.comment: Value should match EvidenceVariable.category.name in the EvidenceVariable referenced in the observed or intended element.

element.short: Definition of the actual variable related to the statistic(s)
element.definition: Definition of the actual variable related to the statistic(s), i.e., the population being the actual study sample or the measured variable (exposure, outcome, or covariate) being the actual observation that occurred or will occur in the study.

element.short: Definition of the intended variable related to the Evidence
element.definition: Definition of the intended variable related to the Evidence, i.e., the population, exposure, or outcome for which the statistical finding is being interpreted.

element.short: low | moderate | high | exact
element.definition: Indication of quality of match between intended variable to actual variable.
element.comment: See the Evidence Based Medicine on FHIR Implementation Guide (https://hl7.org/fhir/uv/ebm) for Extensible and Preferred value sets for evidence-related terminologies.

binding.description: The quality of how direct the match is.

element.short: The design of the synthesis (combination of studies) that produced this evidence
element.definition: The design of the synthesis (combination of studies) that produced this evidence. The design is described with any number of synthesis characteristics, such as type of meta-analysis.
element.comment: See the Evidence Based Medicine on FHIR Implementation Guide (https://hl7.org/fhir/uv/ebm) for Extensible and Preferred value sets for evidence-related terminologies.

binding.description: Types of combining results from a body of evidence (e.g. summary data meta-analysis).

element.short: The design of the study that produced this evidence
element.definition: The design of the study that produced this evidence. The design is described with any number of study design characteristics.
element.comment: See the Evidence Based Medicine on FHIR Implementation Guide (https://hl7.org/fhir/uv/ebm) for Extensible and Preferred value sets for evidence-related terminologies.

binding.description: This is a set of terms for study design characteristics.

element.short: Values and parameters for a single statistic
element.definition: Values and parameters for a single statistic.

element.short: A natural language summary of the statistic
element.definition: A natural language summary of the statistic.

element.short: Footnotes and/or explanatory notes
element.definition: Footnotes and/or explanatory notes.

element.short: Type of statistic, e.g., relative risk
element.definition: Type of statistic, e.g., relative risk. The statistic type is a classification that formally defines the relationship between the variables (noted in Evidence.variableDefinition) and the value specification (noted in Evidence.statistic.quantity).
element.comment: See the Evidence Based Medicine on FHIR Implementation Guide (https://hl7.org/fhir/uv/ebm) for Extensible and Preferred value sets for evidence-related terminologies.

element.short: Associated category for categorical variable
element.definition: When the measured variable (outcome) is handled categorically, the category element is used to define which category the statistic is reporting.
element.comment: Simple strings can be used for descriptive purposes. Exact matching to EvidenceVariable.category.name for the Evidence.variableDefinition[variableRole=outcome].observed=Reference(EvidenceVariable) could facilitate validation within datasets.

element.short: Statistic value
element.definition: Statistic value.

element.short: The number of events associated with the statistic
element.definition: The number of events associated with the statistic, where the unit of analysis is different from numberAffected, sampleSize.knownDataCount and sampleSize.numberOfParticipants.
element.comment: When the number of events is the statistic, use Evidence.statistic.quantity and set Evidence.statistic.type.coding.code=C25463 and Evidence.statistic.type.coding.display=Count. When the statistic is an Event Rate (where individual participants may have 2 or more events), use Evidence.statistic.numberOfEvents to record the total number of events rather than the number of participants with events.

element.short: The number of participants affected
element.definition: The number of participants affected where the unit of analysis is the same as sampleSize.knownDataCount and sampleSize.numberOfParticipants.
element.comment: When the number affected is the statistic, use Evidence.statistic.quantity and set Evidence.statistic.type.coding.code=C25463 and Evidence.statistic.type.coding.display=Count. When the statistic is a Proportion, use Evidence.statistic.numberAffected and enter an integer as the value. When the statistic is an Event Rate (where individual participants may have 2 or more events), use Evidence.statistic.numberAffected to record the number of participants with events rather than the total number of events.

element.short: Count of participants in the study sample
element.definition: Count of participants in the study sample.

element.short: Textual description of sample size for statistic
element.definition: Human-readable summary of study sample size. A human-readable string to clarify or explain concepts about the sample size.

element.short: Footnote or explanatory note about the sample size
element.definition: Footnote or explanatory note about the sample size.

element.short: Number of contributing studies
element.definition: Count of studies or samples combined to become the total sample for the statistic.

element.short: Total number of participants
element.definition: Count of members in the total sample for the statistic.

element.short: Number of participants with known results for measured variables
element.definition: Number of participants with known results for measured variables.

element.short: Total number of participants who were analayzed
element.definition: Total number of participants who were analayzed.

element.short: An attribute of the Statistic
element.definition: A statistical attribute of the statistic such as a measure of heterogeneity.

element.short: Textual description of the attribute estimate
element.definition: Human-readable summary of the estimate.

element.short: Footnote or explanatory note about the estimate
element.definition: Footnote or explanatory note about the estimate.

element.short: The type of attribute estimate, e.g., confidence interval or p value
element.definition: The type of attribute estimate, e.g., confidence interval or p value.
element.comment: See the Evidence Based Medicine on FHIR Implementation Guide (https://hl7.org/fhir/uv/ebm) for Extensible and Preferred value sets for evidence-related terminologies.

element.short: The singular quantity of the attribute estimate, for attribute estimates represented as single values, which may include a unit of measure
element.definition: The singular quantity of the attribute estimate, for attribute estimates represented as single values, which may include a unit of measure.
element.comment: Often the p value

element.short: Level of confidence interval, e.g., 0.95 for 95% confidence interval
element.definition: Use 0.95 for a 95% confidence interval.

element.short: Lower and upper bound values of the attribute estimate
element.definition: Lower and upper bound values of the attribute estimate.

element.short: A nested attribute estimate; which is the attribute estimate of an attribute estimate
element.definition: A nested attribute estimate; which is the attribute estimate of an attribute estimate.
element.comment: A nested attribute estimate; which is the attribute estimate of an attribute estimate

element.short: An aspect of the statistical model
element.definition: A component of the method to generate the statistic.

element.short: Model specification
element.definition: Description of a component of the method to generate the statistic.
element.comment: See the Evidence Based Medicine on FHIR Implementation Guide (https://hl7.org/fhir/uv/ebm) for Extensible and Preferred value sets for evidence-related terminologies.

element.short: The specific value (when paired with code)
element.definition: Further specification of the value of the component of the method to generate the statistic.

element.short: The plan for analysis
element.definition: The plan for analysis.

element.short: This model characteristic is part of the analysis that was applied, whether or not the analysis followed the plan
element.definition: This model characteristic is part of the analysis that was applied, whether or not the analysis followed the plan.
element.meaningWhenMissing: True, unless modelCharacteristic.intended = true; if modelCharacteristic.intended = true and .applied is missing, then meaning Unknown.

element.short: A variable adjusted for in the adjusted analysis
element.definition: A variable adjusted for in the adjusted analysis.

element.short: Description and definition of the variable
element.definition: Description and definition of the variable.

element.short: boolean | continuous | dichotomous | ordinal | polychotomous | time-to-event | not-specified
element.definition: How the variable is classified for use in adjusted analysis.
element.comment: See the Evidence Based Medicine on FHIR Implementation Guide (https://hl7.org/fhir/uv/ebm) for Extensible and Preferred value sets for evidence-related terminologies.

element.short: Qualitative label used for grouping values of a dichotomous, ordinal, or polychotomous variable
element.definition: Qualitative label used for grouping values of a dichotomous, ordinal, or polychotomous variable.

element.short: Quantitative label used for grouping values of a dichotomous, ordinal, or polychotomous variable
element.definition: Quantitative label used for grouping values of a dichotomous, ordinal, or polychotomous variable.

element.short: Range of quantitative labels used for grouping values of a dichotomous, ordinal, or polychotomous variable
element.definition: Range of quantitative labels used for grouping values of a dichotomous, ordinal, or polychotomous variable.

element.short: An attribute of the model characteristic
element.definition: An attribute of the model characteristic.

element.short: Certainty or quality of the evidence
element.definition: Assessment of certainty, confidence in the estimates, or quality of the evidence.

element.short: Textual description of certainty
element.definition: Textual description of certainty.

element.short: Footnotes and/or explanatory notes
element.definition: Footnotes and/or explanatory notes.

element.short: Aspect of certainty being rated
element.definition: Aspect of certainty being rated.
element.comment: See the Evidence Based Medicine on FHIR Implementation Guide (https://hl7.org/fhir/uv/ebm) for Extensible and Preferred value sets for evidence-related terminologies.

binding.description: The aspect of quality, confidence, or certainty.

element.short: Assessment or judgement of the aspect
element.definition: Assessment or judgement of the aspect.
element.comment: See the Evidence Based Medicine on FHIR Implementation Guide (https://hl7.org/fhir/uv/ebm) for Extensible and Preferred value sets for evidence-related terminologies.

binding.description: The assessment of quality, confidence, or certainty.

element.short: Individual or group who did the rating
element.definition: Individual or group who did the rating.

element.short: A domain or subdomain of certainty
element.definition: A domain or subdomain of certainty.
